title: UK government signals it won't cancel Donald Trump's state visit despite petition nearing 1million signatures
text:
News UK government signals it won't cancel Donald Trump's state visit despite petition nearing 1million signatures The US President's travel ban has provoked worldwide outrage - yet No10 said: "The invitation has been extended and accepted" Share A Downing Street spokesman said: "The invitation has been extended and accepted" (Photo: Getty Images North America) Share Get politics updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Downing Street has signalled it has no intention to cancel Donald Trump's state visit to Britain despite a petition to do so nearing a million signatures. 
The US President's travel ban on refugees and citizens from seven Muslim countries has provoked worldwide outrage and chaos. 
Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn led wide calls for Theresa May to cancel Trump's state visit to Britain - which she announced in a White House visit hours before the ban was signed. 
A petition urging the Prime Minister to "prevent" Trump making a state visit had passed 950,000 signatures by 8.40am today. Read More Worldwide fury at Donald Trump's shameful ban on Muslims as US immigration is plunged into crisis 
Yet in response to the furore this morning, a Downing Street spokesman said: "The invitation has been extended and accepted". 
An unknown government source told the BBC cancelling the visit would be a "populist gesture" that would "undo everything". A petition against the state visit was nearing 1million signatures this morning 
A Number 10 source stressed to the Mirror that this was not an official statement from the government. 
Tory MPs, Slumdog Millionaire star Dev Patel and Olympic hero Sir Mo Farah were among those who condemned the "unamerican" ban last night. Read More Ashton Kutcher, Simon Helberg and Dev Patel lead stars condemning Donald Trump's Muslim ban at SAG Awards 
Yet Mrs May, pictured holding Trump's hand on Friday, repeatedly refused to condemn the travel ban - even in a press conference with the Turkish Prime Minister, who did. 
Facing fury from her own party, the Prime Minister eventually backed down with a No10 statement saying she did "not agree" with the travel ban. 
Jeremy Corbyn said: “Trump should not be welcomed to Britain while he abuses our shared values with his shameful Muslim ban and attacks on ­refugees’ and women’s rights.” 
Today the Labour leader's office said it was demanding Boris Johnson comes to Parliament to answer questions on the ban. Boris Johnson is expected to appear in Parliament to field questions on the ban (Photo: Getty) 
"Labour is demanding that the Prime Minister or Foreign Secretary comes to the House to make a statement", a spokesman said. 
Theresa May is due to visit Cardiff today for Brexit talks with Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, leaving Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson expected to appear when the House of Commons hosts urgent questions and statements at 3.30pm. 
Outrage over the state visit was joined today by Muslim former Tory chairwoman Baroness Warsi, who said it sent the "wrong" message. 
She said: "We have to question whether this is something Britain should be doing for a man whose... policies are rooted in divisive rhetoric." 
Distance runner Sir Mo - who said he'd gone from a knight of the realm to feeling "like an alien" - originally believed he would be denied entry to the US because the ban covers Somalia. Sir Mo Farah feared he would be denied entry to the US (Photo: REUTERS) 
Last night the Foreign Office won clarity from the White House that British dual nationals will not be denied entry - only those travelling to the US from the seven named countries. 
And in a chaotic U-turn, Trump's chief of staff Reince Priebus said the ban "doesn't affect" holders of 'green cards' granting them permanent residence - though he later signalled they would still face extra vetting. 
Furious campaigners say this is not good enough as refugees face the chaos of being turned away at airports amid unclear rules. After holding Trump's hand, Theresa May repeatedly refused to condemn the ban (Photo: Christopher Furlong/Getty) 
Responding to the furore, Donald Trump falsely claimed his policy was similar to that of Barack Obama in 2011. 
He also denied the policy was a "Muslim ban" despite clearly saying Christian refugees were a "priority". 
The leader of the free world wrote on Facebook: "To be clear, this is not a Muslim ban, as the media is falsely reporting." 
It was claimed Trump wants to play golf at Balmoral when he pays a state visit - formally offered by the Queen - later this year. What does the travel ban do? 
The travel ban was signed in an executive order by Donald Trump on Friday night. Here is what it does. Bans entry to the US for people born in seven majority Muslim countries - Syria, Iraq, Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan and Yemen for 90 days. It was originally thought to include green card and valid visa holders, but the British Foreign Office claims only those flying from the seven countries - and not British dual nationals - will be affected. Suspends the Syrian refugee plan indefinitely Suspends entire refugee plan for 120 days Prioritises Christian refugees over Muslims Caps refugee total to 50,000 Foreign Office advice for Brits travelling to the US 
This advice was taken at 9am Monday. For latest advice click here. 
You’ll generally qualify to enter the USA using the VWP if your British passport: describes your nationality as a ‘British Citizen’ is an ePassport with this internationally recognised symbol on the front cover 
and you: haven’t been arrested for certain crimes, even if a criminal conviction didn’t result aren’t a dual national of Iran, Iraq, Sudan or Syria haven’t travelled to Libya, Iran, Iraq, Somalia, Sudan, Syria or Yemen since March 2011 have received authorisation from the Electronic System for Travel Authorisation at least 72 hours before you travel (see below) 
can show that you have enough funds available on arrival to support yourself during your stay, even if you’re staying with family and friends 
Certain exemptions apply on a case-by-case basis to those who have travelled to Iran, Iraq, Sudan, Syria, Libya, Somalia or Yemen since March 2011. For more information about these exemptions, see the website of the US Embassy in London or contact the nearest US Embassy or Consulate. Like us on Facebook
